utterances.speaker: system
utterances.text: So to start us off, what comes to mind when you think about oat milk?

utterances.speaker: user
utterances.text: It does not taste like usual milk

utterances.speaker: system
utterances.text: What else do you notice about oat milk when you use it?

utterances.speaker: user
utterances.text: It is watery and does not froth well

utterances.speaker: system
utterances.text: Why does it matter to you that it doesn't froth well?

utterances.speaker: user
utterances.text: I like to pour a well frothed milk froth into my coffee.

utterances.speaker: system
utterances.text: Why is it important to you to have that well-frothed milk in your coffee?

utterances.speaker: user
utterances.text: Froth makes coffee taste less bitter and makes a nice sensation in the mouth

utterances.speaker: system
utterances.text: What is it about having that nice sensation in your mouth that matters to you?

utterances.speaker: user
utterances.text: It feels like a good start of the day and brings positive energy

utterances.speaker: system
utterances.text: Why is starting your day with that positive energy important to you?

utterances.speaker: user
utterances.text: because i can be my best

utterances.speaker: system
utterances.text: What does being your best enable you to do or be in your life?

utterances.speaker: user
utterances.text: I feel proud of myself and set a good example to my kids

utterances.speaker: system
utterances.text: Why is setting a good example for your kids important to you?

utterances.speaker: user
utterances.text: Because i want to be a good father

utterances.speaker: system
utterances.text: What does being a good father mean to you at the deepest level?

utterances.speaker: user
utterances.text: I wish my kids to be happy and successful like me

utterances.speaker: system
utterances.text: When you think about your kids being happy and successful, why does that matter so much to you?

utterances.speaker: user
utterances.text: because i love them

utterances.speaker: system
utterances.text: What does that love mean to you - why is loving them so important?

utterances.speaker: user
utterances.text: they are my kids

utterances.speaker: system
utterances.text: Thank you for sharing your thoughts with me today. This has been very helpful.

nodes.label: does not taste like usual milk
set a good example to my kids

recommendations.detail: All legacy scoring metrics (coverage_score, depth_score, saturation_score) remain 0.0 throughout the entire session, while novelty_score and richness_score are consistently null. These fields are not being computed or populated during the interview process.
recommendations.fix: Either properly compute these metrics in the scoring pipeline or remove them from the schema if deprecated. If computing, ensure the scoring logic populates these fields during each turn.

recommendations.detail: The knowledge graph extracted 20 nodes with appropriate MEAN-END-CHAIN categorization (attribute → functional_consequence → psychosocial_consequence → instrumental_value → terminal_value), but only 3 edges were created. This severely limits the graph's analytical value for understanding the causal chain.
recommendations.fix: Updated extraction prompt (src/llm/prompts/extraction.py) to: 1) Extract both explicit and implicit MEC chain relationships, 2) Added explicit examples for MEC chain extraction, 3) Added aggressive extraction requirement targeting 2-3x more edges than nodes. Status: Implemented, pending verification in next interview.

recommendations.issue: No breadth exploration after depth chain
recommendations.detail: After establishing 'doesn't froth well' and pursuing the depth chain to terminal values, the system never explored other attributes or use contexts (e.g., cereal, drinking straight, baking, price, packaging, sustainability, brand comparisons). The interview became a single deep chain rather than exploring multiple means-end chains as MEC methodology typically requires.
recommendations.fix: After 3-4 consecutive depth steps, explicitly switch to the 'broaden' strategy to explore new attributes and use cases. Implement a depth counter that forces breadth exploration after reaching a threshold.

recommendations.detail: The scoring output is remarkably uniform across all turns: every turn shows final_score of 1.13, DepthBreadthBalanceScorer always reports 'Depth needed', and the reasoning patterns are repetitive. An interview progressing from 'watery' to 'love for my kids' should show evolving metrics that reflect this progression.
recommendations.fix: Make scores more sensitive to interview progression. The metrics should reflect the deepening of the conversation, increasing terminal value discovery, and the shift from attribute exploration to value exploration.
